Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support the conduct of a workshop focused on identifying and evaluating the scientific basis for neuroscience-based learning interventions. The workshop will bring together leading researchers who are working at the intersection of neuro-, cognitive, and educational sciences to address questions pertaining to the theoretical, empirical and methodological bases of interventions and technologies that purport to enhance learning and memory. The workshop will take place in Washington, D.C., in January 2015.

The goals of the workshop are to (a) identify the current state of effective learning interventions and technologies; (b) discuss methodological and statistical challenges that have impeded scientific work in this area and propose solutions to these challenges; and (c) discuss ways of effectively and accurately communicating the scientific literature on neuroscience-based interventions to the broader public. A summary report will be produced that details the products of the discussion and that highlights prospects identified for evidence-based learning techniques based on neuroscientific principles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On January 23, 2015, the White House Office of Science and Technology Programs (OSTP) held a workshop in DC entitled “Bridging Neuroscience and Learning”. The goals of this workshop were to (a) consolidate the current state of knowledge on neuroscience-based learning interventions, (b) identify innovative methodologies that can improve the field’s capacity to inform the development of effective learning interventions, and (c) improve information dissemination to the broader public. Though attendees were brought together to discuss these issues, they were not asked collectively to advise the government. The workshop was interdisciplinary, with attendees from cognitive science, neuroscience, and education backgrounds conducting work on both child and adult populations with some researchers focused on educational and clinical outcomes and others basic science. The interdisciplinary nature of the workshop allowed for the cross-fertilization of ideas, the identification of current themes and problems, and an assessment of current and future capabilities for meeting the challenge of creating innovative and effective learning interventions. Though divergent views on the state of learning interventions were expressed, workshop participants all agreed that the field was at a critical juncture for assessing what has been done, correcting public misinformation regarding the effectiveness of some forms of interventions, and creating a pathway towards a tighter integration between neuroscience and education science.
